children.hint: 3.3.42 Indicate standpipe system class

children.title: Gauges maintaining air and water pressure at normal level.  (13.2.5.1.2)
children.hint: 13.2.5.1.2  Gauges monitoring water pressure shall be inspected quarterly to verify that normal water supply pressure is being maintained. 13.2.5.1.3 Gauges monitoring air or nitrogen pressure shall be inspected monthly to verify that normal air or nitrogen pressure are being maintained.

children.title: System piping and fittings free of mechanical damage, leaks, corrosion, misalignment, or other loads or pipe hung from system  (6.2.1)
children.hint: 6.2.4.1 Piping shall be inspected annually for the following conditions (1) Damaged piping (2) Damaged control valves   5.2.2.1 Pipe and fittings shall be free of mechanical damage, leakage, and corrosion.

children.title: Pipe hangers, braces and supports are secure and undamaged.  (5.2.3)
children.hint: 5.2.3   Sprinkler pipe hangers, braces, and supports shall be inspected annually from the floor level.  5.2.3.1 Hangers, braces, and supports shall not be damaged, loose, or unattached.  5.2.3.2 Hangers, braces, and supports that are damaged, loose, or unattached shall be replaced or refastened

children.title: Hydraulic design sign, if provided, is legible and secure.  (6.2.2.1)
children.hint: 6.2.2.1  A hydraulic design information sign that is missing or illegible shall be replaced.  6.2.2.2 A standpipe system that was not sized by hydraulic design shall have a hydraulic design information sign that reads “Pipe Schedule System.”

children.title: Flow Test for automatic standpipe systems at hydraulically most remote hose connection. (6.3.1.1)
children.hint: 6.3.1.1  A flow test shall be conducted every 5 years on all automatic standpipe systems to verify that the required flow and pressure are available at the hydraulically most remote hose valve outlet(s) while flowing the standpipe system demand. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Nozzle Diameter - Flow test
children.hint: Enter nozzle diameter used for flow testing

children.title: Pitot Pressure -  Flow Test
children.hint: Enter pitot pressure used during flow test

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on gauge at top of riser with designed flow flowing.
children.hint: 6.3.1.1  A flow test shall be conducted every 5 years on all automatic standpipe systems to verify that the required flow and pressure are available at the hydraulically most remote hose valve outlet(s) while flowing the standpipe system demand. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on supply gauge under no flow conditions.
children.hint: Record pressure (psi) shown on supply gauge under no flow conditions.  FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on supply gauge with designed flow.
children.hint: Record pressure (psi) shown on supply gauge with designed flow flowing.  FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Flow (gpm) at most remote outlet?
children.hint: Record flow (gpm) at most remote outlet? FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge error less than 3% full scale or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced.  (13.2.5.2)
children.hint: 13.2.5.2   Gauges shall be replaced every 5 years or tested every 5 years by comparison with a calibrated gauge.   13.2.5.3  Gauges not accurate to within 3 percent of the full scale shall be recalibrated or replaced. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Hydrostatic Test pressure (psi)  (6.3.2.1)
children.hint: 6.3.2.1  Hydrostatic tests of not less than 200 psi (13.8 bar) pressure for 2 hours, or at 50 psi (3.4 bar) in excess of the maximum pressure, where maximum pressure is in excess of 150 psi (10.3 bar), shall be conducted every 5 years on manual standpipe systems and semiautomatic dry standpipe systems, including piping in the fire department connection. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Inside piping without leakage.  (6.3.2.2.1)
children.hint: 6.3.2.2.1 The inside standpipe piping shall show no leakage. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Sprinkler system auxiliary drain(s) drained as needed during this inspection. (Table 6.5.1)
children.hint: Table 6.5.1  Inspect for leaks at system working pressure.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cabinet and parts free from damage, corrosion, & visible or physical obstructions.  (6.2.8.1)
children.hint: 6.2.8.1  Cabinets shall be inspected annually for the following conditions (1) Overall for corroded or damaged parts (8) Visible or physical obstructions.

children.title: Cabinet - lock on break glass-type operates, break glass device attached,  door opens fully and easily, & glazing not cracked or broken.  (6.2.8.1)
children.hint: 6.2.8.1  Cabinets shall be inspected annually for the following conditions (2) Difficult to open (3) Cabinet door not opening fully (4) Door glazing cracked or broken.  (5) Lock on break glass–type cabinet not functioning properly (6) Glass break device missing or not attached.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cap, valve handle, gaskets, and restricting device present and free from damage and deterioration.  (6.2.3.1)
children.hint: 6.2.3.1  Hose connections shall be inspected annually for the following conditions (1) Valve cap(s) missing or damaged ( (3) Valve handles missing or damaged (4) Cap gaskets missing or deteriorated (7) Pressure restricting device missing

children.title: Hose connection without damage, valve free from leakage and no visible or physical obstruction.  (6.2.3.1)
children.hint: 6.2.3.1  Hose connections shall be inspected annually for the following conditions 2) Fire hose connection damaged  (5) Valve leaking (6) Visible and physical obstructions to hose connections  (9) Valve threads damaged.

children.title: Valve operates smoothly.  (6.2.3.1)
children.hint: 6.2.3.1  Hose connections shall be inspected annually for the following conditions  (8) Manual, semiautomatic, or dry standpipe valve does not operate smoothly

children.title: Hose nozzle present, free of obstructions and operates smoothly.  (6.2.6.1)
children.hint: 6.2.6.1 Hose nozzles shall be inspected annually for the following conditions (1) Hose nozzle missing  (3) Obstructions (4) Does not operate smoothly.

children.title: Hose nozzle gaskets present and free of deterioration.  (6.2.6.1)
children.hint: 6.2.6.1 Hose nozzles shall be inspected annually for the following conditions (2) Gasket missing or deteriorated

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve without leaks, handwheel installed and not broken, outlet hose threads undamaged, and hose adapter and cap in place.  (13.5.2.1)
children.hint: 13.5.2.1  All devices shall be inspected annually to verify the following (1) The handwheel is not broken or missing. (2) The outlet hose threads are not damaged. (3) No leaks are present. (4) The hose adapter and the cap are not missing.

children.title: Partial flow test conducted maintaining appropriate pressures.  (13.5.2.3)
children.hint: 13.5.2.3  A partial flow test adequate to move the device from its seat shall be conducted annually.

children.title: Full flow conducted and results compared favorably to previous test results (13.5.2.2)
children.hint: 13.5.2.2  A full flow test shall be conducted on each device at 5-year intervals and shall be compared to previous test results. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Select equipment that are part of water mist system
Enclosures and interlocks in good condition.  (12.2.11)
children.hint: 12.2.11 Enclosures and Interlocks. Semiannually, the integrity of the enclosure and interlocks shall be inspected.

children.title: Water Mist nozzles free of leakage, corrosion, damage, loss of fluid in glass bulb, loading, or paint.  (12.2.1.1.1)
children.hint: 12.2.1.1.1 Any water mist nozzle that shows signs of any of the following shall be replaced  (1) Leakage  (2) Corrosion  (3) Physical damage  (4) Loss of fluid in the glass bulb heat responsive element  (5) Loading  (6) Painting, unless painted by the water mist nozzle manufacturer.

children.title: Replacement nozzles per number of installed nozzles available in head box.  (12.4.2.3.3)
children.hint: 12.4.2.3.3  The supply of spare automatic water mist nozzles  shall be inspected annually for the correct number and type of water mist nozzles as required by NFPA 750; [6.6.7 - (1)For systems having fewer than 50 nozzles, not fewer than 3 nozzles  (2)For systems having 50 to 300 nozzles, not fewer than 6 nozzles  (3)For systems having 301 to 1000 nozzles, not fewer than 12 nozzles  (4)For systems having over 1000 nozzles, not fewer than 24 nozzles].

children.title: Appropriate wrench for each type of spray nozzle provided in spares cabinet.  (12.4.2.4)
children.hint: 12.4.2.4  Where required by the manufacturer, a special water mist nozzle wrench shall be provided and kept in the cabinet to be used for the removal and installation of nozzles. 12.4.2.4.1 One water mist nozzle wrench shall be provided for each type of nozzle installed.

children.title: Piping, tubing & fittings free of damage, leakage & corrosion.  (12.2.3.2)
children.hint: 12.2.3.2  Piping, tubing, and fittings shall be free of mechanical damage, leakage, and corrosion.

children.title: Distribution piping without external loads. (12.2.3.3)
children.hint: 12.2.3.3 Water mist system distribution piping shall not be subjected to external loads by materials either resting on the pipe or hung from the pipe.

children.title: Open Nozzles exposed to environmental residues, replaced or samples tested.  (12.3.2.2)
children.hint: 12.3.2.2  Where water mist nozzles are subjected to environments with residues, including corrosive atmospheres and corrosive water supplies, they shall be either replaced or representative samples tested on a 1-year basis.

children.title: Open Nozzles unable to be discharged annually, and not exposed to environmental residues, replaced or samples tested. (12.3.2.3)
children.hint: 12.3.2.3 Where the nature of the protected property is such that water cannot be discharged annually as indicated in 12.3.16.5 and not subject to the conditions in 12.3.2.2-[Where water mist nozzles are subjected to environments with residues, including corrosive atmospheres and corrosive water supplies, they shall be either replaced or representative samples tested on a 1-year basis.], open water mist nozzles that have been in service for 10 years shall be either replaced or representative samples shall be tested and then retested at 5-year intervals. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Automatic water mist nozzles installed for 10 years have been replaced or sample tested. (12.3.1.2)
children.hint: 12.3.1.2  Automatic water mist nozzles that have been installed for 10 years shall be replaced, or representative samples shall be tested and then retested at 5-year intervals.

children.title: Support frame and restraints in place and secure.  (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: 12.2.5.1.1 Quarterly, compressed gas cylinders shall be inspected for proper securement.

children.title: Control valves in proper position. (12.2.5.8)
children.hint: 12.2.5.8  All manually operated indicating control valves shall be visually inspected to confirm that they are in proper position, at a minimum, semiannually, or in accordance with manufacturer’s specifications

children.title: Pressure within expected range.  (12.2.5.4)
children.hint: 12.2.5.4  The pressure in the high-pressure storage containers shall be within the water mist manufacturer’s specifications.   12.2.5.4.1 Pressure in compressed gas cylinders that are electrically supervised and monitored shall be inspected, at a minimum, semiannually, or in accordance with the manufacturer’s specifications.

children.title: System hoses inspected for damage.  (12.2.5.9)
children.hint: 12.2.5.9  Annually, all hoses used as a part of the system shall be visually inspected for damage.

children.title: Cylinder capacity and pressure rating at required levels.  Compressed gas meets required specifications.  (12.2.5.3)
children.hint: 12.2.5.3  Annually, the cylinder shall be visually inspected for the proper specification, capacity, and pressure rating.

children.title: External inspection of cylinder condition satisfactory.  (12.2.5.2)
children.hint: 12.2.5.2  Compressed gas cylinders continuously in service without discharging shall be given a complete external visual inspection every 5 years or more frequently if required.   A.12.2.5.2 These guidelines apply only to the external inspection of containers continuously in service in the water mist system and should not be confused with the DOT retest requirements for visual inspection described in 49 CFR. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Hydrostatic test performed.  (12.3.6.1)
children.hint: 12.3.6.1 Gas cylinders designed in accordance with U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), Canadian Transport Commission (CTC), or similar containers shall not be recharged without retesting if more than 5 years have elapsed since the date of last test. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valves and tubing without damage. (12.2.6)
children.hint: 12.2.6  Pneumatic Valves and Tubing. Pneumatically operated valves and pneumatic tubing shall be visually inspected, at a minimum, semiannually, or in accordance with the manufacturer’s specifications.

children.title: On-off cycle valves and slave valves operate in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.  (12.3.12.2)
children.hint: 12.3.12.2 Semiannual testing of the following pneumatic valves shall be conducted for operation in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions (1) Slave valves (2) Valves intended to cycle on–off

children.title: Pneumatic valves respond, automatically and manually, as designed. (12.3.13.1)
children.hint: 12.3.13.1  Operational tests shall be conducted to ensure the pneumatic valve solenoid releases for the water mist system responds as designed, both automatically and manually.

children.title: Pneumatic cylinder release valves reset after testing. (12.3.13)
children.hint: 12.3.13  Pneumatic Valve Solenoid Releases.   All pneumatic cylinder release valves shall be reset after testing.

children.title: Manual and electric solenoid releases respond as designed. (12.3.13.1)
children.hint: 12.3.13.1  Operational tests shall be conducted to ensure the pneumatic valve solenoid releases for the water mist system responds as designed, both automatically and manually.   12.3.13.2  Annual testing of the following pneumatic solenoid valve releases shall be conducted for operation in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions  (1) Electric release   (2) Manual release.

children.title: Cylinders without damage or corrosion.  (12.2.7.1)
children.hint: 12.2.7.1  Quarterly, the storage cylinder shall be visually inspected for external corrosion or damage.

children.title: Quantity of additive agent adequate.  (12.2.7.2)
children.hint: 12.2.7.2  Semiannually, the quantity of the additive agent shall be inspected.

children.title: Manual and automatic operational tests respond as designed. (12.3.5.1)
children.hint: 12.3.5.1  Operational test shall be conducted to ensure the injection rate of the additive for the water mist system responds as designed, both automatically and manually

children.title: Automatic fire detection system operates as designed. (12.3.5.5)
children.hint: 12.3.5.5 Under test conditions, the automatic fire detection systems, when exposed to a test source, shall operate within the requirements of NFPA 72 for the type of detector provided, and the response time shall be recorded.   12.3.5.6 The time lapse between operation of detection systems and water delivery time to the protected area shall be recorded for open discharge devices.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
What equipment is part of Foam System?
children.hint: Select all equipment that is part of foam system

children.title: Foam water discharge devices in place, aimed properly, & free from corrosion or external loading (11.2.4.1)
children.hint: 11.2.4.1 Foam-water discharge devices shall be inspected visually and maintained to ensure that they are in place, continue to be aimed or pointed in the direction intended in the system design, and are free from external loading and corrosion.

children.title: All rubber-gasket fittings in fire area protected by water spray discharge.  (11.2.2)
children.hint: 11.2.2  System piping and fittings shall be inspected for the following  (5) Protection for rubber-gasketed fittings

children.title: System piping free of mechanical damage, damaged coating, rust, corrosion, & misalignment.  (11.2.2)
children.hint: 11.2.2  System piping and fittings shall be inspected for the following  (1) Mechanical damage (e.g., broken piping or cracked fittings)  (2) External conditions (e.g., missing or damaged paint or coatings, rust, and corrosion)  (3) Misalignment or trapped sections.

children.title: All pipe hangers and supports secure and undamaged (11.2.3)
children.hint: 11.2.3 Hangers, Braces, and Supports. Hangers, braces, and supports shall be inspected for the following and repaired or replaced as necessary (1) Condition (e.g., missing or damaged paint or coating, rust, and corrosion) (2) Secure attachment to structural supports and piping (3) Damaged or missing hangers, braces, and supports.

children.title: Low point drains in place and not damaged.  (11.2.2)
children.hint: 11.2.2  Piping and Fittings. System piping and fittings shall be inspected for the following  (4) Condition of low-point drains (automatic or manual)

children.title: Blow-down valve closed and plugged.  (11.2.6.4)
children.hint: 11.2.6.4 Foam concentrate strainers shall be inspected visually to ensure the blowdown valve is closed and plugged

children.title: Discharge device strainers removed, and cleaned.  (11.2.6.3)
children.hint: 11.2.6.3 Discharge device strainers shall be removed, inspected, and cleaned during the flushing procedure for the mainline strainer.

children.title: Drainage facilities free of obstructions, dikes and retention embankments in good repair.  (11.2.7)
children.hint: 11.2.7 Drainage. The area beneath and surrounding a foam water spray system shall be inspected to ensure that drainage facilities, such as trap sumps and drainage trenches, are not blocked and retention embankments or dikes are in good repair.

children.title: Water supply regularly  inspected to ensure dependable operation, and water supply piping free of internal obstructions.  (11.2.5.1 & 11.2.5.2)
children.hint: 11.2.5.1 The dependability of the water supply shall be ensured by regular inspection and maintenance, whether furnished by a municipal source, on-site storage tanks, a fire pump, or private underground piping systems.  11.2.5.2  Water supply piping shall be maintained free of internal obstructions.

children.title: Valves in proper (open/closed)  position.  (11.2.8.3)
children.hint: 11.2.8.3 The position (open or closed) of valves shall be verified in accordance with specified operating conditions.

children.title: Level of foam concentrate in supply tank adequate  & foam concentrate storage tank free of external corrosion.  (11.2.8.4 & 11.2.8.5.2.2 (2))
children.hint: 11.2.8.4 Inspection of the concentrate tank shall include verification that the quantity of foam concentrate satisfies the requirements of the original design.  11.2.8.5.2.2  (2) An inspection for external corrosion on foam concentrate storage tanks

children.title: Proportioning system responded correctly, automatically and manually.  (11.3.2.1)
children.hint: 11.3.2.1 Operational tests shall be conducted to ensure that the foam-water sprinkler system(s) responds as designed, both automatically and manually.

children.title: Samples of foam-water concentrate mixture taken during full flow testing and checked verifying concentration of solution within 10% of acceptance test results.  (11.3.5.1)
children.hint: 11.3.5.1 During the operational test, a foam sample shall be taken.   11.3.5.4 The foam concentrate induction rate of a proportioner, expressed as a percentage of the foam solution flow (water plus foam concentrate), shall be within minus 0 percent to plus 30 percent of the manufacturer’s listed concentration, or plus 1 percentage point, whichever is less. [168.4.1.4]

children.title: Response time.  (11.3.2.4)
children.hint: 11.3.2.4  Under test conditions, the automatic fire detection systems, when exposed to a test source, shall operate within the requirements of NFPA 72 for the type of detector provided, and the response time shall be recorded.

children.title: Time (secs) between operation of detection system and water delivery.  (11.3.2.5)
children.hint: 11.3.2.5  Discharge Time. The time lapse between operation of detection systems and water delivery time to the protected area shall be recorded for open discharge devices.

children.title: Pressure (psi) at highest, most remote discharge device.  (11.3.2.7.1)
children.hint: 11.3.2.7.1  Pressure readings shall be recorded at the highest, most remote discharge device.

children.title: Pressure (psi) at main control valve.  (11.3.2.7.3)
children.hint: 11.3.2.7.3  A second pressure reading shall be recorded at the main control valve.   11.3.2.7.4  Readings shall be compared to the hydraulic design pressures to ensure the original system design requirements are met.

children.title: Proportioner
children.hint: Common Questions for all Proportioners

children.title: Water surrounding bladder free of foam and water control valves in correct position.  (11.2.8.5.2.2))
children.hint: 11.2.8.5.2.2  The inspection shall include the following (1) Water control valves to foam concentrate tank (3) An inspection for the presence of foam in the water surrounding the bladder (annual)

children.title: Sight glass, if provided, removed and cleaned.  (11.4.5.1)
children.hint: 11.4.5.1  Sight glass, where provided, shall be removed and cleaned. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Hydrostatic test for foam concentrate bladder tank @ system working pressure.  (11.4.5.2)
children.hint: 11.4.5.2  The foam concentrate bladder tank shall be hydrostatically tested at system working pressure.  11.4.5.2.1  The hydrostatic test shall not create a pressure differential across the diaphragm.  11.4.5.2.2  While under system working pressure, the exterior of the foam concentration bladder tank shall be inspected for leaks.

children.title: Strainer clear and pressure vacuum vent operating freely, power available to foam liquid pump. (11.2.8.5.5)
children.hint: 11.2.8.5.5   In-Line Balanced Pressure Proportioner. The inspection shall include the following (1) Strainers  (2) Verification that pressure vacuum vent is operating freely  (5) Verification that power is available to foam liquid pump

children.title: Gauges in good working condition, and sensing lines at pump unit and proportioner station are open.  (11.2.8.5.5)
children.hint: 11.2.8.5.5   In-Line Balanced Pressure Proportioner. The inspection shall include the following (3) Verification that gauges are in good working condition  (4) Verification that sensing line valves at pump unit and individual proportioner stations are open

children.title: Time (secs) between operation of detection system and water delivery.  (11.3.2.5)
children.hint: 11.3.2.5  Discharge Time. The time lapse between operation of detection systems and water delivery time to the protected area shall be recorded for open discharge devices.

children.title: Foam pump, drive train, and drivers serviced.  (11.4.8.2)
children.hint: 11.4.8.2  Servicing.  Foam pumps, drive train, and drivers shall be serviced in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions and frequency but not at intervals of more than 5 years.

children.title: Diaphragm balancing valve flushed through diaphragm section with water or foam concentrate until fluid appears clear or new.  (11.4.8.3)
children.hint: 11.4.8.3  Flushing  The diaphragm balancing valve shall be flushed through the diaphragm section with water or foam concentrate until fluid appears clear or new.

children.title: Foam liquid tank inspected for internal and external corrosion and sediment, with excessive sediment drained and flushed from tank.  (11.4.8.4)
children.hint: 11.4.8.4  The foam concentrate tank shall be inspected internally for corrosion and sediment.   11.4.8.4.2  Excessive sediment shall require draining and flushing of the tank.

children.title: Foam concentrate tank drained and flushed.  (11.4.6.3)
children.hint: 11.4.6.3  The foam concentrate tank shall be drained and flushed.

children.title: Foam concentrate tank inspected for internal corrosion, and pickup pipes inspected for corrosion, separation or plugging.  (11.4.6.1)
children.hint: 11.4.6.1  The foam concentrate tank shall be inspected for internal corrosion.  11.4.6.2  Pickup pipes inside the tank shall be inspected for corrosion, separation, or plugging.

children.title: Diaphragm balancing valve flushed through the diaphragm section until fluid appears clear or new.  (11.4.7.3)
children.hint: 11.4.7.3  Flushing. The diaphragm balancing valve shall be flushed through the diaphragm section with water or foam concentrate until fluid appears clear or new. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Foam pump, drive train, and drivers serviced.  (11.4.7.2)
children.hint: 11.4.7.2  Servicing. Foam pumps, drive train, and drivers shall be serviced in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions and frequency but not at intervals of more than 5 years. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Foam concentrate tank inspected for internal and external corrosion and sediment, w/excessive sediment drained and flushed from tank.  (11.4.7.4)
children.hint: 11.4.7.4.1  The foam concentrate tank shall be inspected internally for corrosion and sediment.   11.4.7.4.2  Excessive sediment shall require draining and flushing of the tank. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Ball drip valves (auto drains) free and opened; foam concentrate storage tank free external corrosion. (11.2.8.5.1.2)
children.hint: 11.2.8.5.1.2 The inspection shall verify the following  (1) Ball drip valves (automatic drains) are free and opened.  (2) External corrosion on foam concentrate storage tanks is not present

children.title: Ball drip valves (automatic drains) disassembled, cleaned and reassembled.  (11.4.4.1)
children.hint: 11.4.4.1  The ball drip (automatic-type) drain valves shall be disassembled, cleaned, and reassembled. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Foam liquid storage tank drained of foam liquid and flushed.  (11.4.4.2)
children.hint: 11.4.4.2  The foam liquid storage tank shall be drained of foam liquid and flushed.

children.title: Foam liquid tank inspected for internal, external corrosion and hydrostatically tested to the specified working pressure.  (11.4.4.4)
children.hint: 11.4.4.4  The foam liquid tank shall be inspected for internal and external corrosion and hydrostatically tested to the specified working pressure.

children.title: Sprinkler system auxiliary drain(s) drained as needed during this inspection and inspected for leaks.  (Table 11.5.1)
children.hint: Table 11.5.1  Inspect for leaks at system working pressure.

children.title: Detectors in place, securely fastened, & protected from mechanical damage & corrosion.  (13.9.2)
children.hint: 13.9.2 Automatic detection equipment used to actuate waterbased fire protection systems that is not covered by NFPA 72 shall be inspected, tested, and maintained to ensure that the detectors are in place, securely fastened, and protected from corrosion, weather, and mechanical damage.

children.title: Communication wiring, control units, or tubing system is functional.  (13.9.2)
children.hint: 13.9.2 Automatic detection equipment used to actuate waterbased fire protection systems that is not covered by NFPA 72 shall be inspected, tested, and maintained to ensure that the communication wiring, control panels, or pneumatic tubing system is functional.

children.title: Vent opening not blocked, vent body flushed and drained, & vacuum valve and pressure valve cleaned thoroughly.  (11.4.9.2 & 11.4.9.5)
children.hint: 11.4.9.2  The vent shall be inspected to ensure that the opening is not blocked and that dirt or other foreign objects do not enter the tank.   11.4.9.5  The vent body shall be flushed internally, and the vacuum valve and the pressure valve shall be washed thoroughly.

children.title: Vent reassembled with appropriate lubrication, vent bonnet replaced and moveable parts have freedom of movement.  (11.4.9.10)
children.hint: 11.4.9.10 Parts shall be sprayed with a light Teflon® coating, and the vent shall be reassembled.  11.4.9.11 The use of any type of oil for lubrication purposes shall not be permitted.  11.4.8.12 The vent bonnet shall be replaced, and the vent shall be turned upside down slowly a few times to ensure proper freedom of the movable parts.

children.title: Discharge devices in place, pointed/aimed in direction per system design, and  free from external loading and corrosion.  (11.2.4.1)
children.hint: 11.2.4.1 Foam-water discharge devices shall be inspected visually and maintained to ensure that they are in place, continue to be aimed or pointed in the direction intended in the system design, and are free from external loading and corrosion.  11.2.4.3 Misaligned discharge devices shall be adjusted (aimed) by visual means, and the discharge patterns shall be inspected at the next scheduled flow test.

children.title: Caps or plugs (if required) are in place and free to operate as intended,  (11.2.4.2)
children.hint: 11.2.4.2 Where caps or plugs are required, the inspection shall confirm they are in place and free to operate as intended.

children.title: Discharge devices do not have unlisted combinations and foam concentrate has not be substituted.  (11.2.4.4)
children.hint: 11.2.4.4 Inspection shall verify that unlisted combinations of discharge devices and foam concentrate have not been substituted.

children.hint: List of Deficiencies for Foam System

children.title: Select equipment in the Fire Service Main
Hydrant inspected for damage, and any vegetation is cleared around hydrant for minimum of 3 ft.
children.hint: 7.2.2.6 Dry Hydrants. Dry hydrants shall be inspected at least quarterly and maintained as necessary to keep them in good operating condition. 7.2.2.6.2 Vegetation shall be cleared for a mimimum 3 ft (0.9m) radius from around hydrants.

children.title: Hydrant accessible, without cracks in barrel or leaks in outlets or top of hydrant. (7.2.2.4/7.2.2.5)
children.hint: 7.2.2.4  Dry barrel and wall hydrants shall be inspected annually and after each operation for the following conditions:  (1) Inaccessibility  (2) Presence of water or ice in barrel, which could indicate a faulty drain, a leaky hydrant valve, or high groundwater table)  (3) Improper drainage from barrel   (4) Leaks in outlets or at top of hydrant  (5) Cracks in hydrant barrel       7.2.2.5 Wet barrel hydrants shall be inspected annually and after each operation for the following conditions:  (1) Inaccessibility   (2) Leaks in outlets or at top of hydrant  (3) Cracks in hydrant barrel

children.title: Outlet caps tight, outlet threads and hydrant operating nut not worn and operating wrench available.  (7.2.2.4/7.2.2.5))
children.hint: 7.2.2.4  Dry barrel and wall hydrants shall be inspected annually and after each operation for the following conditions:    (6) Tightness of outlet caps  (7) Worn outlet threads  (8) Worn hydrant operating nut   (9) Availability of operating wrench    7.2.2.5 Wet barrel hydrants shall be inspected annually and after each operation for the following conditions:   (4) Tightness of outlet caps  (5) Worn outlet threads  (6) Worn hydrant operating nut  (7) Availability of operating wrench

children.title: Hydrant barrel without corrosion that is detrimental to hydrant integrity.  (7.2.2.4/7.22.5)
children.hint: 7.2.2.4  Dry barrel and wall hydrants shall be inspected annually and after each operation for the following conditions  (2) Presence of water or ice in barrel, which could indicate a faulty drain, a leaky hydrant valve, or high groundwater table.  (5) Cracks in hydrant barrel  (10)  Corrosion detrimental to hydrant integrity.

children.title: Hydrant opened fully and water flowed until all foreign material has cleared and proper drainage observed.  (7.3.2.1 & 7.3.2.3)
children.hint: 7.3.2.1 Each hydrant shall be opened fully and water flowed until all foreign material has cleared.   7.3.2.2  Flow shall be maintained for not less than 1 minute.   7.3.2.3 After operation, dry barrel and wall hydrants shall be observed for proper drainage from the barrel.

children.title: Hydrant parts lubricated.  (7.4.2.1)
children.hint: 7.4.2.1 Hydrants shall be lubricated annually to ensure that all stems, caps, plugs, and threads are in proper operating condition.

children.title: Exposed piping free of leaks, physical damage, corrosion, hanging or restraint problems.  (7.2.2.1.2)
children.hint: 7.2.2.1.2 Piping shall be inspected for the following conditions (1) Leaks (2) Physical damage (3) Corrosion (4) Restraint methods

children.title: Strainers removed and inspected for plugging, fouling, damaged or corroded parts.  (7.2.2.3.2)
children.hint: 7.2.2.3.1 Mainline strainers shall be inspected and cleaned after each system flow exceeding that of a nominal 2 in. (50 mm) orifice.    7.2.2.3.2  Mainline strainers shall be removed and inspected annually for plugging, fouling, and damaged and corroded parts.

children.title: Hydrant outlet size (flow hydrant)
children.hint: Indicate size of hydrant outlet or nozzle size of flowing hydrant.

children.title: Residual psi (residual hydrant)
children.hint: Residual reading from pressure hydrant during full flow. (7.3.1)  (pressure when valve is open)

children.title: Static psi  (residual hydrant)
children.hint: Static reading from pressure hydrant during no flow. (7.3.1)  (pressure when valve is closed)

children.title: Pitot pressure (flow hydrant)
children.hint: Enter the pitot pressure used for testing. (7.3.1)

children.title: Flow test results show piping free of pipe degradation that would affect system performance.   (7.3.1.1)
children.hint: 7.3.1.1  Any flow test results that indicate deterioration of available waterflow and pressure shall be investigated to the complete satisfaction of the authority having jurisdiction to ensure that the required flow and pressure are available for fire protection.

children.hint: Select type of severity

children.hint: List of Deficiencies for Hydrant

children.title: Monitor nozzle free of any leaking, corrosion or physical damage.  (7.2.2.7)
children.hint: 7.2.2.7  Monitor nozzles shall be inspected semiannually for the following conditions (1) Leakage (2) Physical damage (3) Corrosion.

children.title: Monitor nozzle oscillated & moved through full range & lubricated for proper operation. (7.3.3.2 & 7.4.3)
children.hint: 7.3.3.2  All monitor nozzles shall be oscillated and moved throughout their full range annually to ensure proper operability.  7.4.3 Monitor Nozzles. Monitor nozzles shall be lubricated annually to ensure proper operating condition.

children.title: Hydrant mounted monitor nozzle, tested for proper functioning.  (7.3.3.1)  Enter N/A if not applicable.
children.hint: 7.3.3.1  Monitor nozzles that are mounted on hydrants shall be tested as specified in 7.3.2.

children.title: Tank Type
children.hint: Select type of tank(s) at location.

children.title: Exterior of tank, supporting structure, vents, foundation and catwalks/ladders, where provided, free of obvious damage or weakening?  (9.2.4.1)
children.hint: 9.2.4.1  The exterior of the tank, supporting structure, vents, foundation, and catwalks or ladders, where provided, shall be inspected quarterly for signs of obvious damage or weakening.

children.title: Area around tank free of combustibles, corrosive materials or ice buildup.  (9.2.4.2)
children.hint: 9.2.4.2  The area surrounding the tank and supporting structure, where provided, shall be inspected quarterly to ensure that the following conditions are met  (1) The area is free of combustible storage, trash, debris, brush, or material that could present a fire exposure hazard.  (2) The area is free of the accumulation of material on or near parts that could result in accelerated corrosion or rot.  (3) The tank and support are free of ice buildup.

children.title: Area around tank free of combustibles, corrosive materials or ice buildup, and embankment supporting tanks free of erosion.  (9.2.4.2)
children.hint: 9.2.4.2  The area surrounding the tank and supporting structure, where provided, shall be inspected quarterly to ensure that the following conditions are met  (1) The area is free of combustible storage, trash, debris, brush, or material that could present a fire exposure hazard.  (2) The area is free of the accumulation of material on or near parts that could result in accelerated corrosion or rot.  (3) The tank and support are free of ice buildup.  (4) The exterior sides and top of embankments supporting coated fabric tanks are free of erosion.

children.title: Hoops and grillage free of damage.  (9.2.4.4)
children.hint: 9.2.4.4 The hoops and grillage of wooden tanks shall be inspected annually.

children.title: Exterior painted, coated or insulated surfaces and supporting structures, if provided, free of signs of degradation? (9.2.4.5)
children.hint: 9.2.4.5  Exterior painted, coated, or insulated surfaces of the tank and supporting structure, where provided, shall be inspected annually for signs of degradation.

children.title: Interior of tank free of damage, corrosion, deterioration, failure of interior coating or aquatic growth.  (9.2.5.1.1)
children.hint: 9.2.5.1.1  The interior of steel tanks without corrosion protection shall be inspected every 3 years.  9.2.5.3 The tank interior shall be inspected for signs of pitting, corrosion, spalling, rot, other forms of deterioration, waste materials and debris, aquatic growth, and local or general failure of interior coating.

children.title: Interior of tank free of damage, corrosion, deterioration or aquatic growth? (9.2.5.3)
children.hint: 9.2.5.3 The tank interior shall be inspected for signs of pitting, corrosion, spalling, rot, other forms of deterioration, waste materials and debris, aquatic growth, and local or general failure of interior coating.

children.title: Silt drained from tank to avoid accumulation to the level of tank outlet.  (9.4.5)
children.hint: 9.4.5 Silt shall be removed during interior inspections or more frequently as needed to avoid accumulation to the level of the tank outlet.

children.title: Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge accurate within 3%  of full scale or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced.  (13.2.5.2 & 13.2.5.3)
children.hint: 13.2.5.2  Gauges shall be replaced every 5 years or tested every 5 years by comparison with a calibrated gauge.  13.2.5.3  Gauges not accurate to within 3 percent of the full scale shall be recalibrated or replaced.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Deficiencies
children.hint: List deficiencies for tank system

children.title: Isolation valves in normal open position and properly secured.  (9.5.1.1.1)
children.hint: 9.5.1.1.1  OS&Y isolation valves that are a part of the automatic fill valves shall be inspected in accordance with Chapter 13.  13.3.1.3 Each normally open valve shall be secured by means of a seal or a lock or shall be electrically supervised in accordance with the applicable NFPA standards.

children.title: Strainers cleaned. (9.5.2.3)
children.hint: 9.5.2.3  Strainers shall be cleaned quarterly.

children.title: Valve actuated, tank refill rate is appropriate.  (9.5.3)
children.hint: 9.5.3  All automatic tank fill valves shall be tested yearly in accordance with the following  (1) The valve shall be actuated automatically by lowering the water level in the tank.  (2) The refill rate shall be measured and recorded.

children.title: Strainers, filters, orifices inspected and cleaned as needed.  (Table 9.5.1.1)
children.hint: Table 9.5.1.1  Alarm valves and their associated strainers, filters, and restriction orifices shall be inspected internally every 5 years unless tests indicate a greater frequency is necessary.  13.4.1.2 (Wet), 13.4.3.1.3 (Preaction), 13.4.4.1.3 (Deluge)

children.title: Heating system including piping working properly, without leaks or obvious damage during cold weather.  (9.2.2.1)
children.hint: 9.2.2.1 Tank heating systems installed on tanks equipped with low water temperature alarms supervised in accordance with NFPA 72 , connected to a constantly attended location shall be inspected quarterly during the heating season.

children.title: Tank heating system maintaining water temperature at proper level.  (9.3.2)
children.hint: 9.3.2 The tank heating system, where provided, shall be tested prior to the heating season to make certain it is in the proper working order.

children.title: Level indicator operating accurately and has freedom of movement.  (9.3.1)
children.hint: 9.3.1 Level indicators shall be tested every 5 years for accuracy and freedom of movement.

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on Supply Water pressure gauge.
children.hint: 13.2.3  Main Drain Test.  A main drain test shall be conducted annually for each water supply lead-in to a building water based fire protection system to determine whether there has been a change in the condition of the water supply.  A13.2.3  The main drain test is conducted in the following manner  (1) Record the pressure indicated by the supply water gauge.

children.title: Residual Pressure with valve open.
children.hint: 13.2.3  Main Drain Test.  A main drain test shall be conducted annually for each water supply lead-in to a building water based fire protection system to determine whether there has been a change in the condition of the water supply.  A13.2.3  The main drain test is conducted in the following manner  (4) After the flow has stabilized, record the residual (flowing)  pressure indicated by the water supply gauge.

children.title: Static Pressure after valve closed.
children.hint: 13.2.3  Main Drain Test.  A main drain test shall be conducted annually for each water supply lead-in to a building water based fire protection system to determine whether there has been a change in the condition of the water supply.

children.title: Main Drain Test Pressure less than 10% reduction in flow from original acceptance test or previous test results.
children.hint: 13.2.3.3  When there is a 10 percent reduction in full flow pressure when compared to the original acceptance test or previously performed tests, the cause of the reduction shall be identified and corrected if necessary.

children.title: Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge error less than 3% full scale or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced.  (13.2.7.2)
Take a picture of the issue
Valve has proper signs, and is accessible.
children.hint: 13.3.2.2  The valve inspection shall verify that the valves are in the following condition: (3) Accessible  (6) Provided with applicable identification.

children.title: Valve is free of external leaks, and appropriate wrench available for PIV.
children.hint: 13.3.2.2  The valve inspection shall verify that the valves are in the following condition: (4) Post indicator valves (PIVs) are provided with correct wrenches  (5) Free from external leaks.

children.title: Valve in normal  position and properly secured.
children.hint: 13.3.2.2  The valve inspection shall verify that the valves are in the following condition: (1) In the normal open or closed position (2) Sealed, locked, or supervised

children.title: Valve exercised through full range to ensure proper operation.
children.hint: Annual Freq. Requirement.  13.3.3.1  Each control valve shall be operated annually through its full range and returned to its normal position.  13.3.3.2  Post indicator valves shall be opened until spring or torsion is felt in the rod, indicating that the rod has not become detached from the valve.  13.3.3.3 Post indicator and outside screw and yoke valves shall be backed a one-quarter turn from the fully open position to prevent jamming.

children.title: Valve Status Test - Valves open when returned to service.
children.hint: 13.3.3.4  A valve status test shall be conducted any time the control valve is closed and reopened at system riser.

children.hint: List deficiencies for control valve

children.title: Valve in open position, not leaking and with handwheel installed and unbroken.  (13.5.1.1)
children.hint: 13.5.1.1 All valves shall be inspected quarterly to verify that the valves are in the following condition (1) In the open position  (2) Not leaking  (4) Handwheels installed and unbroken

children.title: Valve maintaining downstream pressure in accordance with design.  (13.5.1.1)
children.hint: 13.5.1.1 All valves shall be inspected quarterly to verify that the valves are in the following condition (3) Maintaining downstream pressures in accordance with the design criteria

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on Water supply side pressure gauge.
children.hint: Record Pressure (psi) shown on Water supply side pressure gauge.

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on System side pressure gauge.
children.hint: Record Pressure (psi) shown on System side pressure gauge.

children.title: Partial flow test conducted adequate to move the valve clapper from its seat.  (13.5.1.3)
children.hint: 13.5.1.3  A partial flow test adequate to move the valve from its seat shall be conducted annually

children.title: At full flow test, valve closes and maintains appropriate pressure compared to previous test results.   (13.5.1.2)
children.hint: 13.5.1.2   A full flow test shall be conducted on each valve at 5-year intervals and shall be compared to previous test results. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge is accurate within 3% of full scale or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced.  (13.2.5.2)
children.hint: 13.2.5.2  Gauges shall be replaced every 5 years or tested every 5 years by comparison with a calibrated gauge.   13.2.5.3 Gauges not accurate to within 3% of the full scale shall be recalibrated or replaced. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

children.title: Riser check valves gauges show normal water pressure is maintained  (13.4.1.1)
children.hint: 13.4.1.1  Alarm valves and system riser check valves shall be externally inspected quarterly and shall verify the following:  (1) The gauges indicate normal supply water pressure is being maintained.  (2) The valves and trim are free of physical damage.  (3) All valves are in the appropriate open or closed position.  (4) The retarding chamber or alarm drains are not leaking

children.title: Valves & trim free of physical damage, & valves in normal position.  (13.4.1.1)
children.hint: 13.4.1.1  Alarm valves and system riser check valves shall be externally inspected quarterly and shall verify the following:  (1) The gauges indicate normal supply water pressure is being maintained.  (2) The valves and trim are free of physical damage.  (3) All valves are in the appropriate open or closed position.  (4) The retarding chamber or alarm drains are not leaking

children.title: Internal inspection with valve components operating correctly.  (13.4.2.1)
children.hint: 13.4.1.1  Alarm valves and system riser check valves shall be externally inspected quarterly and shall verify the following:  (1) The gauges indicate normal supply water pressure is being maintained.  (2) The valves and trim are free of physical damage.  (3) All valves are in the appropriate open or closed position.  (4) The retarding chamber or alarm drains are not leaking. FREQUENCY SET TO ANNUAL TO ALLOW A GREATER FREQUENCY IF NECESSARY. NFPA REQUIREMENT IS STILL 5YR.

options.text: Underground and Exposed Piping Flow Test

children.title: FDC visible and accessible, and signs in place.
children.hint: 13.8.1 Fire department connections shall be inspected quarterly to verify the following (1) Fire department connections are visible and accessible.  (5) Identification signs are in place.

children.title: Couplings and swivels free of damage and rotate smoothly.
children.hint: 13.8.1 Fire department connections shall be inspected quarterly to verify the following (2) Couplings or swivels are not damaged and rotate smoothly.

children.title: Caps, plugs and gaskets in place and free from damage.
children.hint: 13.8.1 Fire department connections shall be inspected quarterly to verify the following (3) Plugs or caps are in place and undamaged. (4) Gaskets are in place.

children.title: Check valve free from leaks, automatic drain valve and clapper in place and operating properly.
children.hint: 13.8.1 Fire department connections shall be inspected quarterly to verify the following (6) Check valve is not leaking. (7) Automatic drain valve is in place and operating properly. (8) Fire department connection clapper(s) is in place and operating properly.

children.title: Interior of the connection free of obstructions.
children.hint: 13.8.1 Fire department connections shall be inspected quarterly to verify the following (9) Interior of the connection is inspected for obstructions.   13.8.2 Interior inspections shall be conducted annually if approved locking caps or locking plugs are installed.

children.title: Visible piping supplying FDC undamaged.
children.hint: 13.8.1 Fire department connections shall be inspected quarterly to verify the following (10) Visible piping supplying the fire department connection is undamaged.

children.title: Internal inspection of check valve - components operate properly, cleaned/repaired as needed.
children.hint: 13.4.2.1 Inspection. Valves shall be inspected internally every 5 years to verify that all of the valve’s components operate correctly.

children.title: Hydrostatic test results of piping from FDC to check valve acceptable.
children.hint: 13.8.5 The piping from the fire department connection to the fire department check valve shall be hydrostatically tested at 150 psi (10 bar) for 2 hours at least once every 5 years.

children.title: Inspectors Test Valve
children.hint: Inspectors Test Connection

children.title: Flow test results show piping free of pipe degradation that would affect system performance.   (7.3.1)
children.hint: 7.3.1  Underground and exposed piping shall be flow tested at minimum 5 yr intervals.   7.3.1.1 Any flow test results that indicate deterioration of available waterflow and pressure shall be investigated to the complete satisfaction of the authority having jurisdiction to ensure that the required flow and pressure are available for fire protection.

children.title: Underground and Exposed Piping Flow Test
Assessment method used.  (14.2.1)
children.hint: 14.2.1 An assessment of the internal condition of piping shall be conducted on a frequency determined by 14.2.1.1 or 14.2.1.2 for the purpose of inspecting for the presence of foreign organic and inorganic material.  A.14.2.1 for methods.

children.title: No foreign material found to be obstructing pipe or sprinklers.  (14.2.1.4)
children.hint: 14.2.1.4  If the presence of sufficient foreign organic or inorganic material is found to obstruct pipe or sprinklers, an obstruction investigation shall be conducted as described in Section 14.3.

children.title: Piping without tubercules or slime.  (14.2.1.3)
children.hint: 14.2.1.3 Tubercules or slime, if found, shall be tested for indications of microbiologically influenced corrosion (MIC).

children.title: Internal pipe condition assessment results. (14.2.1.1)
children.hint: 14.2.1.1 An assessment of the internal condition of piping shall be conducted at a minimum of every 5 years or in accordance with 14.2.1.2 for the purpose of inspecting for the presence of foreign organic and inorganic material.

children.title: Reason for conducting obstruction investigation.
children.hint: 14.3.2 Systems shall be examined for internal obstructions where conditions exist that could cause obstructed piping.

children.title: Assessment method used.  (14.3.2.3)
children.hint: 14.3.2.3 Alternative nondestructive examination methods.

children.title: Examination of interior system valve.  (14.3.2.2)
children.hint: 14.3.2.2 Internal examination shall be performed at the following minimum four points (1) System valve  (2) Riser  (3) Cross main (4) Branch line
